Nicholas Maxwell, a modern philosopher, argued that the basic aim of academic inquiry ought to be to seek and promote wisdom - wisdom being construed to be the capacity to realize what is of value in life for oneself and others, wisdom thus including knowledge and technological know-how, but much else besides.
  +          
==Scientific perspectives==
 
==Scientific perspectives==
−   −
For the last 30 years, the scientific research literature has been formally addressing the topic of ‘'''W'''isdom’, especially as Western [[economies]] begin to transition from a Manufacturing & Industry Age model into a [[Science]] & [[Technology]] [[Information Age]] model.
  −   −
‘'''W'''isdom’, from a scientific perspective, is viewed as an integral component of the '''[[Data]]''' to '''[[Information]]''' to '''[[Knowledge]]''' scientific [[learning]] pathway. The [[DIKW]] scientific [[learning]] pathway, especially as practiced by scientific [[learning organizations]] is intimately connected with the [[scientific method]] itself.
  −   −
‘'''W'''isdom’, from a scientific perspective, could be viewed simply as ‘[[knowledge]] in context’. Yet functionally, ‘'''W'''isdom’ is far more textured and multidimensional.
  −
The modern western scientist who has conducted the most visible and thoughtful research on this topic is [[Jonas Salk]], in his companion reports “[[Survival Of The Wisest]]” ( [http://www.amazon.com/survival-wisest-Jonas-Salk/dp/006013738X] ) and “[[Anatomy Of Reality]]” ( [http://www.amazon.com/s/ref=nb_ss_b/104-7050689-6708737?url=search-alias%3Dstripbooks&field-keywords=Anatomy+of+Reality&Go.x=8&Go.y=5] ).
  −
  −
For his research in the field of investigation into the nature of scientific wisdom, Jonas Salk was inducted into the Academy of Achievement in Washington DC in 1976. Many of Salk’s central observations about scientific ‘wisdom’ were cited in the issuance of this special recognition, as cited in the [[Academy of Achievement]] website ( [http://www.achievement.org/autodoc/page/sal0int-8] ).
  −
Moreover, this same dimension of Salk’s research was critically reviewed in an in-depth [[University of Chicago]] study about the professional lives of America’s most enduringly-successful scientists ( '''''“Creativity: Flow and the Psychology of Discovery and Invention”''''' [ [http://www.amazon.com/Creativity-Flow-Psychology-Discovery-Invention/dp/0060928204/ref=sr_1_1/104-2738267-6438361?ie=UTF8&s=books&qid=1173657555&sr=1-1] ] ).
  −   −
In his research on scientific wisdom, Salk operationally defines the scientific experience of ‘'''W'''isdom’ in this progressive fashion (paraphrased):
  −
  −
1. The acquisition of scientific mastery & [[competency]], based upon an authentic appreciation of the field;
  −   −
2. The acquisition of scientific [[purpose]];
  −
  −
3. The acquisition of skills for improving the [[knowledge]]-, [[learning]]-, and [[value]]-creation-assets of one’s scientific [[community of practice]]; and
  −   −
4. The ability to create timely scientific solutions that are pleasing to Man, while not being in violation of the timeless laws of [[Nature]].
  −   −
In its simplest form, Salk summarized his scientific research on ‘'''W'''isdom’ with the “'''Good Ancestor Principle'''” ( [http://www.nsf.gov/news/speeches/colwell/rc81012.htm] ):
  −   −
'''''“…the most important question we must ask ourselves is ‘Are we being good ancestors?’ Given the rapidly changing discoveries and conditions of the time, this opens up a crucial conversation – just what will it take for our descendants to look back upon our decisions today and judge us good ancestors?”'''''
  −   −
As America, and many other Western nations, enter the [[Science]] & [[Technology]] [[Information Age]], the expressed need for more-sophisticated [[scientific]] [[understandings]] of all levels of the [[scientific]] [[learning]] pathway – including the acquisition of scientific wisdom -- continues to grow: It is likely that further refinements in ‘what scientific wisdom is’ and ‘what scientific wisdom isn’t’ will likely keep pace with the demand.
  −
